オプション1: A week later, Star Man kept searching for an island but couldn't find one.

Trapezoid Man kept weaving baskets.
After a week of practice, he could make large, sturdy baskets
with a tight weave.

They attached shoulder straps, and Star Man and the kids began
heading out with them on their backs.

The children gathered coconuts and acorns.
They also tried catching fish with baskets,
but didn't catch a single one.
One day, when Star Man came home, the kids were holding stone spears.
"Star Man, we tried making these—take one with you tomorrow."
Trapezoid Man handed Star Man a handmade stone spear.
"Oh... thanks."

"Same with the baskets—if we keep making them, they'll get better.
If you see improvements, tell me."
"Got it."
Over the week, they gave the monsters names.

They named the cube‑shaped monster "Cube" and the spherical one "Sphere"—
just as they were.

During the week Star Man had encountered a Cube twice as big
and a Cube half the size; he named them Big Cube and Small Cube.

Star Man made a habit of practicing magic every day.
For now, throwing stones was more effective on monsters than his magic.

Even so, because there was a ghost that only magic worked on,
he kept training just in case.
One day, when Star Man returned to Precision, grilled fish had been set out.
"Those kids finally did it (laughs). There's one for you in the next room too."
said Trapezoid Man.
"Then I'll gratefully partake as well."
Star Man went to the next room.
Square Man brought a fish skewered on a wooden stick.
"Here you go."
"Thanks."

Star Man bit into the grilled fish.
Having eaten only acorns and coconuts, he savored every bite.
"How did you catch it?"

"We sank the net, and when a fish swam over it,
we lifted the net and caught it."
said Triangle Man.
"I see."
(I'll try it too...)
Star Man decided that tomorrow he'd walk toward the mountains.
